meaning: a good thing that seemed bad at first
example: Losing that job turned out to be a blessing in disguise for him as it forced him to plunge into business.

meaning: Something very common and not having much value
example: Adventure and traveling based reality shows are now outdated and a dime a dozen

meaning: Avoid saying what you mean, usually because it is uncomfortable
example: Will you please stop beating about the bush and get to the point?

meaning: Better to arrive late than not to come at all
example: All of us have been waiting for you for two hours - but better late than never.

meaning: To endure a painful experience that you cannot avoid
example: When the time comes, I'll bite the bullet and take my punishment without a fuss.

meaning: Good luck
example: "Break a leg!" shouted the stage director to his actors before the beginning of the play.

meaning: Stop working on something
example: After second heart attack, she decided it would be best to follow her doctor's advice and call it a day

meaning: Give additional freedom to someone
example: I know he is not up to the mark right now but let's cut him some slack. He's new to this environment and needs time to adjust.

meaning: Doing something poorly in order to save time or money
example: It is certainly not a sensible move to cut corners with national security.

meaning: Used to tell someone to go ahead with something with slowly, and carefully
example: Sandra: I asked him for a simple drawing! To be honest, I am so angry right now. Andrew: Easy does it, Sandra. We will make sure he refunds the money.

meaning: Get out of control
example: When the police arrived, they realised the party was getting out of hand.

idiom: Get something out of your system
meaning: Do the thing you've been wanting to do so you can move on
Get organized and on schedule
example: The official was asked to get his act together if he wanted to keep his post.

meaning: Regards a person as innocent unless confirmed otherwise
example: Let's give her the benefit of the doubt and assume that she is right.

meaning: Back to the planning stage
example: My experiment was a failure, so I'm back to the drawing board.

meaning: Wait, be patient till things work out
example: Our company is going through tough times, but we're hanging in there; things will surely work out.

meaning: Go to sleep
example: I am really tired after all that exercise. I am going to hit the sack.

meaning: It's not complicated
example: I've no idea why Kelly can't make a spreadsheet, and it's not exactly rocket science is it?

meaning: To not hold someone responsible for something
example: Since it was his first offence, and a minor one at that, he was let off the hook with just a warning.

meaning: Abbreviate a long explanation into a short one
example: To make a long story short, he still stays in the apartment but now it is owned by someone else.

meaning: It's too late
example: The discounted price sale ended today and I just missed the boat on making a great deal.

meaning: You have to work for what you want
example: If you want to win the title next month, you have to train for an extra hour every day next week. No pain, no gain.

meaning: Alert to new trends, ideas, and methods
example: The mother is glad to know that her son is always on the ball to learn new things in class.

meaning: To joke with someone
example: Don't worry about what he said. He's just pulling your leg.

meaning: To calm down and behave normally after an upsetting event
example: I know its difficult to get over your loss, but try to pull yourself together and get on with life.

meaning: Things are going well so far
example: Thanks for asking; so far, so good.

meaning: When someone comes in unexpectedly while being talked about
example: We were huddled together in our lunch table, talking about our boss, when he walked in. Well, speak of the devil!

meaning: To be the last in a sequence of unpleasant things
example: The last straw in their relationship was when he physically abused her. She walked out after that.

meaning: A win-win situation
example: If you decide to live here you get the greenery of the countryside and the amenities of urban life. Its the best of both worlds really.

meaning: For a particular phase in life to seem shorter than it really was
example: Time flies when I go to play with friends.

idiom: To get bent out of shape
meaning: To get upset
Make a problem worse
To be ill or feel ill
example: I did not go to work today, as I was feeling a bit under the weather.

meaning: To delay worrying about something that might not happen anyway
example: We think that there may be too many people to fit into the hall, but we will cross that bridge when we come to it.

meaning: Understand something complicated
Used to agree with another person or group of people
example: She said, "This horrible weather has been killing me." He said - "You can say that again!"

idiom: Your guess is as good as mine
meaning: I have no idea
example: If you want to know which one is the best of these movies, well, your guess is as good as mine.

idiom: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush
meaning: What you have is worth more than what you might have later
example: You may not like your job, but don't quit merely on the hope of finding a better one. A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.

meaning: A way of asking what someone else is thinking
example: You have been quiet for a while a penny for your thoughts.

idiom: A penny saved is a penny earned
meaning: This phrase advises people to be cautious of their money and have savings.
example: Now that he has financial difficulties he will realize that a penny saved is as good as a penny earned.

meaning: the worst possible situation
Better to show than tell
What you do carries more weight than what you say
example: "You always speak of the importance of charity, but never do anything. Actions speak louder than words!"

meaning: To make a bad situation worse
example: "The company rejected his application for a job, and to add insult to injury, refused to pay his expenses."

meaning: Waste one's efforts by pursuing the wrong thing or path
example: It was a very sensitive case and yet for over one year the investigators kept barking up the wrong tree.

idiom: Birds of a feather flock together
meaning: People who are alike are often friends (usually used negatively)
example: The team is divided into people from the same region batting against each other. Birds of a feather flock together.

idiom: Bite off more than you can chew
meaning: Try to do more than one is able to do
example: By accepting two part-time jobs, he is clearly biting off more than he can chew.

meaning: To do or say something that makes people feel more comfortable, especially at the start of a meeting or party
example: Jone suggested playing a party game to break the ice

idiom: By the skin of your teeth
meaning: Barely manage to do something
example: We managed to complete the project on time by the skin of our teeth.

meaning: Comparing two things that cannot be compared
example: We cannot compare Sara and Salina. They are apples and oranges.

idiom: Costs an arm and a leg
meaning: Very expensive

idiom: Do something at the drop of a hat
meaning: Do something without having planned beforehand

idiom: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you
meaning: Treat people fairly. Also known as 'The Golden Rule'

idiom: Don't count your chickens before they hatch
meaning: Don't count on something good happening until it's happened.
There's no reason to complain about something that can't be fixed

idiom: Don't give up your day job
meaning: You're not very good at this

idiom: Don't put all your eggs in one basket
meaning: What you're doing is too risky

idiom: Every cloud has a silver lining
meaning: Good things come after bad things

idiom: Get a taste of your own medicine
meaning: Get treated the way you've been treating others (negative)
Ignore someone

idiom: Go on a wild goose chase
meaning: To do something pointless

idiom: Good things come to those who wait
meaning: Be patient

idiom: He has bigger fish to fry
meaning: He has bigger things to take care of than what we are talking about now

idiom: He's a chip off the old block
meaning: The son is like the father

idiom: Hit the nail on the head
meaning: Get something exactly right
You're better off not knowing

idiom: It ain't over till the fat lady sings
meaning: This isn't over yet

idiom: It takes one to know one
meaning: You're just as bad as I am
It's easy
It's raining hard

idiom: Kill two birds with one stone
meaning: Get two things done with a single action

idiom: Let the cat out of the bag
meaning: Give away a secret
I made a mistake
Take only calculated risks
On probation. If you make another mistake, there will be trouble.
Rarely
To argue the opposite, just for the sake of argument
Put a projet on hold
To spoil something
Saving money for later

idiom: Slow and steady wins the race
meaning: Reliability is more important than speed
Give away a secret
Postpone a plan

idiom: Take it with a grain of salt
meaning: Don’t take it too seriously

idiom: The ball is in your court
meaning: It's your decision

idiom: The best thing since sliced bread
meaning: A really good invention

idiom: The devil is in the details
meaning: It looks good from a distance, but when you look closer, there are problems

idiom: The early bird gets the worm
meaning: The first people who arrive will get the best stuff
The big issue, the problem people are avoiding
Everything, all the way.

idiom: There are other fish in the sea
meaning: It's ok to miss this opportunity. Others will arise.

idiom: There's a method to his madness
meaning: He seems crazy but actually he's clever

idiom: There's no such thing as a free lunch
meaning: Nothing is entirely free
Take a risk

idiom: You can't have your cake and eat it too
meaning: You can't have everything

idiom: You can't judge a book by its cover
meaning: This person or thing may look bad, but it's good inside

idiom: A little learning is a dangerous thing
meaning: People who don't understand something fully are dangerous
Events have momentum and build upon each other
No chance at all

idiom: A stitch in time saves nine
meaning: Fix the problem now because it will get worse later
A big fuss about a small problem

idiom: An apple a day keeps the doctor away
meaning: Apples are good for you

idiom: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure
meaning: You can prevent a problem with little effort. Fixing it later is harder.
Perfect
Something that happened without warning
Destroy relationships
Something bad is coming, but right now it's calm
No matter what
Stop asking questions
Do a good job
Move on, this subject is over
Everyone gets a chance at least once
The better you know someone the less you like him
In good health
Take risks
Have more energy after having been tired
Hear news of something secret
Fail spectacularly
You'll make mistakes if you rush through something

idiom: Have your head in the clouds
meaning: Not be concentrating

idiom: He who laughs last laughs loudest
meaning: I'll get you back for what you did

idiom: Hear something straight from the horse's mouth
meaning: Hear something from the person involved

idiom: He's not playing with a full deck
meaning: He's dumb
He's crazy
He can't make up his mind

idiom: It is a poor workman who blames his tools
meaning: If you can't do the job, don't blame it on others

idiom: It is always darkest before the dawn
meaning: Things are going to get better
One person alone isn't responsible. Both people are involved.
Follow a trend, do what everyone else is doing

idiom: Know which way the wind is blowing
meaning: Understand the situation (usually negative)
Look everywhere
Stop discussing an issue
Something you never forget how to do

idiom: Like two peas in a pod
meaning: They're always together

idiom: Make hay while the sun shines
meaning: Take advantage of a good situation
Very happy
You're more cautious when you've been hurt before

idiom: Out of the frying pan and into the fire
meaning: Things are going from bad to worse
Run fast
Work better or leave
Busy
It's too late

idiom: The pot calling the kettle black
meaning: Someone criticizing someone else he is just as bad

idiom: There are clouds on the horizon
meaning: Trouble is coming

idiom: Those who live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones
meaning: People who are morally questionable shouldn't criticize others
In good times and in bad times
Work quickly
Don't waste things and you'll always have enough
We agree
Go through something difficult
Getting a good start is important
Everything is going wrong at once

idiom: You can catch more flies with honey than you can with vinegar
meaning: You'll get what you want by being nice

idiom: You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make him drink
meaning: You can't force someone to make the right decision

idiom: You can't make an omelet without breaking some eggs
meaning: There's always a cost to doing something
